channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description: @countscreamalot @Osinttechnical They are also ostensibly designed to self-inert 100 hours after deployment.
@AmbreEarnhart @UAWeapons Remote-control (especially fixed-wing) aircraft have been homebuilt and successfully flown for many decades, by individual hobbyists all over the world.
@eqbullero98 @dapotter42 @LucasFoxNews The United States does also not control the door. If they didn’t follow the rules, they would risk not being allowed through the Bosphorus in the future.
@Blacklace40 They can’t now - Turkey won’t let them pass due to treaty obligations. (The only way in would be to ‘gift’ the ships to Romania or Ukraine.)
@TimandHonor @LovedayM The Uragen 9M27K (the carrier missile, not the individual ‘passenger’ cluster bombs) appears to have just such a nosecone: https://t.co/jP4fhJFlVJ

@tipesca @Megamin91343928 @InnaSovsun Yeah, the playground clearly wasn’t the target. (It was nearby, though.) The caption may have been misleading, but the photo appears authentic. — — — Bottom line: there’s too much collateral damage in any war. Perhaps our grandchildren will be more peaceful than us.

@AshDom12 @HaywardScoreCEO It would be constantly alarming? (Seriously, though, I heard Japan? had been using inexpensive CO2 sensors as a proxy for measuring occupancy + fresh air exchange rate to some good effect.)
@vasabjit_b At least half of that tank’s log is still usable.

@tipesca @Megamin91343928 @InnaSovsun It looks like a booster-stage rocket casing, as was seen with their cluster bomb missiles - the explosive payload likely continued onward towards its target with a second/third stage rocket motor. The minimal damage shown is solely due to the kinetic energy upon impact.
@OvertDefense @TrentTelenko Can those be easily armed / re-used by Russian forces without a working TB2?

@cmvalentineb @ClaireBurdett @ninuxch @DirkStrongtall @ndcarson @kathrinpassig @teh_skullz @TrentTelenko Improved transmission capacity can mitigate much of the need for batteries, and will be needed anyway when fusion power becomes available in the 2050-2090 time frame. Spending the next 50 years improving grid infrastructure worldwide will pay dividends for our grandchildren.

@TrentTelenko Does that not keep for more than one season if not planted now? (honest question - I’ve never farmed anything) Couldn’t at least some ‘EU-compatible’ seed corn that was needed be imported from elsewhere in the EU (or even from Russia, as part of some sort of reparations scheme)?

@TrentTelenko It’s easy forget how large Ukraine actually is… … isn’t it plausible that the number of acres of farmland never even within shouting distance of military vehicles is at least an order of magnitude larger than the number _directly_ touched by forces from either side?
“corruption cannot be centralized” There’s never just one termite. https://t.co/5QyEcHKKwc
Did you or a friend see shocking news? Please sleep on it, or at least do some fact-checking, prior to sharing. “The war shortfall is 0.9% of the global wheat crop! Not 25%!” https://t.co/hl3IgVZpgS

@jrochest @mvhElmore @kamilkazani It’s an interesting strategy for purely industrial substations, though. Anti-drone defenses, in the rare places they exist, might ignore drones too small to carry significant explosives, for example, but if consumer-level drones could do something like this…

@br92168132 @GwizoKeith @TrentTelenko You may also be interested in his (@kamilkazani’s) other recent threads, summarized here: (he also has an article, posted on his 2nd Substack site, called “Why is Russia so big?” - highly recommended, even for those deeply familiar with the region’s history) https://t.co/gNXh7QI33B
@Deer_Hirsch @GwizoKeith @TrentTelenko Clipboards and checklists. Grease pencils. More checklists. So many checklists. (I have it on good authority that Powerpoint is an offensive cyber-weapon.)
